posts.post_content:
Shuffle isn't useless. It's just not worth paying 1 (effectively 2) red mana to do it, even if it is repeatable and near-indestructible. This can be a good counter to some strategies, but that makes it an extremely situational sideboard card at best. It might be worth playing if your metagame is fond of deck manipulation and that's about it.  
  
Bottom line: it has its place. Its EXTREMELY SMALL place. 1.5/5.
posts.html:

Bottom line: it has its place. Its EXTREMELY SMALL place. 1.5/5.

Posted By: nimzo (3/1/2011 11:43:27 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
This could be perfect for a U/R EDH deck (Nim, Pain Artist, Niv-Mizzet the Firemind, Jhoira of the Ghitu anyone?) You could probably utilise the shuffle effect to make sure you don't get dead draws like lands. Works especially well with [Sensei's Diving Top](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sensei's Diving Top), [Counterbalance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Counterbalance), [Future Sight](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name= Future Sight), [Halimar Depths](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Halimar Depths), [Jace the Mindsculptor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jace the Mindsculptor), Brainstorm etc. Basically stuff that involves library manipulation.   
Although in my own deck, the red is for a splash, and I don't really ever have many red permanents (lands are colourless btw)...

Posted By: UltimaCenturion (8/10/2009 12:56:58 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Actually shuffling before every draw helps you get lands.  
  
  
Here let me explain.  
Lets say your next land is 10 cards deep. You have a 1% chance of that happening, but your roll is cast and your royally screwed without you knowing it.  
  
1/100 is pretty bad luck right? It can happen though...  
But if your "rolling" every draw, what are the odds of scoring 1/100 10 times in a row?  
Multiple rolls = better chances of not getting screwed.
posts.html:
Actually shuffling before every draw helps you get lands.


Here let me explain.
Lets say your next land is 10 cards deep. You have a 1% chance of that happening, but your roll is cast and your royally screwed without you knowing it.

1/100 is pretty bad luck right? It can happen though...
But if your "rolling" every draw, what are the odds of scoring 1/100 10 times in a row?
Multiple rolls = better chances of not getting screwed.

2/5. If it said "target player shuffles his or her library" it would be glorious. Then you could screw up [Counterbalance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Counterbalance), and you could respond to "put the card on top of your library" tutors.  
  
Shuffling is not really a red thing, is it? I wonder if "deals 1 damage to target creature" turned out to be overpowered in testing. They had to have thought of that first.
